Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigation of Spectrum Sharing Between Radar and Wireless Communications Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will enable more efficient use of a scarce resource, the radio spectrum. This project will have broad impact on the public by enabling increased efficiency in communications between citizens, while simultaneously shared use of the same frequency range for radar applications. The techniques developed will potentially reduce the impact by both accidental and intentional (jamming) interference. Students, who will carry out part of the research, will be better trained to join the US work force. Furthermore, their use of the research in the classroom presentations will lead to a keener appreciation of the use and issues faced by permitting widespread use of cognitive radio devices, devices that can change its wireless channel at will.

This proposal explores the potential for Synthetic Aperture Radars to operate with other users of the spectrum. In particular it aims to explore the capacity for a Radar system to operate efficiently by recognizing and discarding false positive signals; in effect by using a variety schemes to identify and ignore interference. Their approach is unique in that it attempts to integrate the spectrum sharing into the fundamental operation of the radar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this effort we have developed an innovative virtual transmit-receive beamforming algorithm based on coherent (multiple-input multiple-output) MIMO radar architecture that can be used to effectively eliminate wireless interferences from both mainlobe and sidelobe directions.  In addition, we have discovered that a space-time waveform design approach for MIMO radar can be employed to essentially make the radar radiation powers in certain wireless base station directions almost zeros and thus the spectrum-sharing between MIMO radar and wireless systems possible.  Another significant achievement in this effort is that we developed several radar interference and target identification algorithms based on AI techniques to effectively detect radar targets even with strong and unfiltered wireless interferences at radar receover. Finally, we developed two general radar-wireless coexistent systems for spectrum sharing. One of them is implementing wireless communications functions through radar sidelobe radiations. The data rate of the imbedded communications system is higher than other similar systems. The other radar-wireless coexistence approach is achieving passive radar target detection and measurement by using LTE wireless signals as radar target illumination sources.  Our pioneering work on radar-wireless spectrum-sharing, once considered to be technically impossible, could significantly improve the data transmission capability of the future wireless systems. In addition, the radar radiation management through waveform design developed in this effort will have interesting applications for future covert radar operation.  Our research results were documented and disseminated through the production of one monograph and more than 30 peer-reviewed technical publications. Furthermore, through this project a radar research lab was built at Florida International University (FIU); and two Ph.D. , five Master and more than 20 undergraduate students were trained or graduated in  radar and wireless communications fields.
